item.title: Saudi Arabia’s Stock Market Goes Global
item.description: Saudi Arabia recently opened its stock exchange, Tadawul, to all foreign investors, an important structural shift for the Gulf region. But when deciding whether to invest, foreigners will scrutinize the quality of the exchange's corporate-governance regulations, which will likely need to be fine-tuned.

item.title: Rogue America Is Changing the Global Economic Outlook
item.description: Since the year began, US President Donald Trump has ramped up his aggression in the Western Hemisphere, including military intervention in Venezuela and threats to impose large sanctions on European Union countries that oppose US annexation of Greenland. Suddenly, the international order – institutions, understandings, and alliances – that underpinned economic growth for generations are at risk.

item.title: The Big Picture
Trump’s Robber-Baron Imperialism
item.description: By normalizing territorial predation and treating foreign policy as a vehicle for personal enrichment, Donald Trump is putting America’s economy and credibility at risk. Democrats and Republicans who oppose Trump must speak up now or inherit a world where US prosperity and security have been damaged beyond repair.

item.title: Europe Needs Joint Financing and Procurement to Defend Itself
item.description: Despite rising military spending, the European Union’s defense capabilities remain constrained by fragmented procurement, uneven national budgets, and weak coordination. Bolstering resilience and reducing dependence on the United States will require mobilizing resources at the European level.

item.title: History Marches Past Davos
item.description: The World Economic Forum meeting in Davos will feature the usual pledges about stakeholder capitalism, purpose-driven business, and sustainable development. But without binding conditionalities, accountability frameworks, and risk-sharing that distinguish genuine value creators from rent extractors, it remains theater.

item.title: Is There Life After the Dollar?
item.description: Global financial stability has long depended on the dollar’s role as the main reserve currency, with the expectation that the United States would both set the rules and uphold them. As American leadership grows more erratic, that dependence has become a vulnerability, underscoring the need for a multicurrency system.

item.title: Superintelligence Is Not the Answer to Climate Change
item.description: Tech evangelists view climate change as an information problem that the arrival of AI superintelligence will solve, rather than a willpower problem that requires concrete measures, like modernizing the electrical grid and implementing a carbon tax. But there can be no miracle fix once critical planetary tipping points are crossed.

item.title: Trump Is Serving US Imperialism Raw
item.description: While previous instances of American gunboat diplomacy often paid lip service to human rights or democracy, Donald Trump has dispensed with idealistic justifications for military intervention abroad. Everyone, not least Europe, now confronts behavior that was already familiar to many across the Global South.

item.title: Britain Must Lead the Pushback Against Trump
item.description: To ensure that Greenland remains a territory of Denmark, British Prime Minister Keir Starmer and other European leaders must put pressure on NATO’s most powerful member. Given the US president’s love of royalty, one way to do that would be to organize a public meeting between British King Charles III and Danish King Frederik X.

item.title: The Biggest Questions About Venezuelan Oil
item.description: Some analysts have suggested that Donald Trump seized control of Venezuela’s oil reserves to boost profits for US refineries or to lower energy prices for American consumers by flooding the global market with crude. But this resource grab is most likely motivated by greed, as well as the desire to curb China’s access to energy.

item.title: Trump Is Putting Venezuelan Democracy on Hold
item.description: Nicolás Maduro’s removal initially raised hopes that Venezuelans would finally regain control over their political future. Instead, US President Donald Trump has chosen to preserve the Chavista power structure, sidelining pro-democracy advocates and leaving opposition leader María Corina Machado with little influence.

item.title: As Climate Diplomacy Stalls, the Economics Are Racing Ahead
item.description: Despite political gridlock within countries and at global summits, climate change and ecological degradation are creating undeniable economic momentum. As renewables scale up, fossil fuels will become even less competitive; and as ecosystems degrade, markets will price in the risks and reward those who adapt.

item.title: The Fight Over the Fed
item.description: The US Federal Reserve’s independence is widely understood to be vital to the economy’s well-being, by insulating monetary policy from political imperatives. But, following the launch of a criminal investigation of Fed Chair Jerome Powell by President Donald Trump’s minions at the Department of Justice, it is hanging on by a thread.

item.title: The Big Picture
Trump’s Petrostate Dilemma in Venezuela
item.description: By capturing his Venezuelan counterpart Nicolás Maduro, US President Donald Trump sought to project power abroad but instead exposed his own political vulnerability. Despite his promises to restore Venezuela’s oil industry, his overt resource grab is far more likely to fuel regional turmoil.

item.title: The AI Takeover of All Media Is Coming
item.description: Not only is AI already upending the filmmaking industry, but Hollywood is just one example of how the technology will cause enormous social and economic pain unless managed humanely and carefully. Fiction writing, commercial photography, radio, music, and – most ominously – journalism and legacy news outlets face a similar reckoning.

item.title: How to Feed Ten Billion People
item.description: With the world’s population expected to reach ten billion by mid-century, agriculture must produce more with less – every season, everywhere. The knowledge and tools to end and prevent food insecurity are already in hand, but they have yet to be used wisely and at scale.

item.title: The Impact of Impact Investing
item.description: As a venture-capital pioneer and co-founder of Apax Partners, Sir Ronald Cohen experienced firsthand the emergence of an investment framework based on rigorously measured risk and return. How plausible is Cohen's claim that a new revolution is underway, one which adds social, environmental, or development outcomes to the equation?

item.title: Navigating the Trump-Powell Feud
item.description: The latest attacks on the US Federal Reserve by Donald Trump's administration are raising fears of a grim future of unanchored inflation expectations, macroeconomic instability, and heightened financial volatility. But internal and external checks and balances are likely to prove sufficiently robust to prevent a major accident.
